Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Pacific Undergraduate Research Experience in Mathematics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Pacific Undergraduate Research Experience in Mathematics (PURE Math) is a dual-tiered, academic mentoring program targeting U.S. Pacific Islanders and other underrepresented groups in the mathematical sciences. This collaborative 5-year MCTP program will be housed at the University of Hawai?i at Hilo (UHH) and administered, staffed, and managed by 4 faculty members at UHH and Sam Houston State University (SHSU). PURE Math will have a lasting, positive impact on 114 STEM undergraduates interested in the mathematical sciences and several junior faculty members who wish to engage students in research. PURE Math has two primary goals. The first is to increase the number of native Pacific Islanders earning degrees and pursuing careers in the mathematical sciences; PURE Math will focus on mentoring these students through their transition from computational problems to more theoretical concepts. The second goal is to provide valuable and lasting mentoring experiences to junior faculty at UHH, who will be trained in directing undergraduate research.

PURE Math will offer an innovative, two-tiered advanced mathematics program over five summers that consists of an Interns program and a Residents program. The Interns program is a 5-week advanced mathematics workshop in which 60 lower-level undergraduates will discover topics not typically included in an undergraduate mathematics curriculum. The Residents program is an 8-week summer undergraduate research experience introducing 54 upper-level undergraduates to active fields of mathematics led by seasoned researchers. These summer experiences will allow PURE Math student participants to transition effectively from lower-level computational work to upper-level abstract work, and from undergraduate research to graduate work. PURE Math will ultimately encourage a lasting environment of undergraduate mathematical research in the Pacific Islands. Furthermore, it will add to the growing infrastructure of research and atmosphere of mathematical collaboration between undergraduates and faculty.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Pacific Undergraduate Research Experience in Mathematics (PURE Math) was a 5-year Mentoring through Critical Transition Points program, which was housed at the University of Hawai'i at Hilo (UHH) and administered, staffed and managed by faculty at UHH and Sam Houston State University (SHSU). The PURE Math Program was the first dual-tiered academic mentoring program designed to broaden participation in the mathematical sciences by establishing the first of what we hope will be many research opportunities for Native Hawai`ians, U.S. Pacific Islanders and other severely underserved and underrepresented groups in the mathematical sciences. PURE Math had two primary goals:

  1. Increase the number of native Hawai`ians and Pacific Islanders earning degrees and pursuing careers in the mathematical sciences through a community focused on mentoring students through several critical transition points:
    • from lower-level computational coursework to upper-level theoretical coursework;
    • from working on textbook problems to open-ended research problems; and
    • from undergraduate work to graduate work.
  2. Provide valuable and lasting mentoring experiences to faculty at UHH through the following two critical transition points:
    • from lecture-based teaching to running a discovery-based learning environment and
    • from the traditional role of teaching and research to directing undergraduate

To obtain these goals, the directors of PURE Math developed and carried out an innovative two-tiered program designed to mentor and to cultivate the mathematical talent of undergraduates at different educational levels. From 2011 to 2015, twelve undergraduates (mostly rising juniors) participated in a 5-week long PURE Math Interns program. From 2012 to 2015, twelve undergraduates (mostly rising seniors) concurrently participated in an 8-week long PURE Math Residents program. All students engaged in a significant research experience on an advanced mathematical topic: they began their summers in intense discovery-based academic seminars and spent the remainder of the program working in groups on projects developed by seasoned academic advisors. In addition, students were required to attend the following weekly workshops developed by the PURE Math directors:

  1. Using LaTeX, professional typesetter for manuscripts and publications in the mathematical sciences,
  2. How to prepare oral and poster presentations using and on tips in giving a good presentation,
  3. Applying to graduate school in the mathematical sciences and various types of external funding,
  4. Preparing for and taking the math subject GRE,
  5. Careers in the mathematical sciences,
  6. Research and employment opportunities for undergraduates,
  7. SAGE, a mathematics software system utilized by the students for their research and mini-projects. 

Each summer, a diverse group of highly successful research mathematicians visited the PURE Math Program. As part of their visit, each mathematician gave a research talk on their active area of research and shared their inspiring journey toward becoming a research mathematician and overcoming obstacles along their way. The summer would conclude with the submission of a technical report and an oral presentation of their research at a PURE Math Symposium. In the following academic year, PURE Math provided funding for its participants to attend various national conferences, most notably the annual Joint Mathematics Meetings, the National SACNAS Conference and the Field of Dreams Conference. All attending participants presented posters of their summer results at the conferences and were able to network with representatives from graduate programs in the mathematical sciences.
